wikipedia_page.main: Frederick Wyld (28 August 1847 – 11 February 1893) was an English first-class cricketer active from 1868 to 1885 who played for Nottinghamshire. He was born at Eastwood, Nottinghamshire and died at Nottingham. He appeared in 180 first-class matches as a right-handed batsman and wicket-keeper who occasionally bowled right arm roundarm fast. He scored 3,967 runs with a highest score of 104 not out, one of two centuries in his career. He held 185 catches and completed 53 stumpings. He took 8 wickets with a best performance of four for 33.

response: He died at Bentley with Arksey, Yorkshire on 20 November 1951. His uncle Frederick Wyld also played first-class cricket.

link_mentions.page: MCC v Australians at Lord's, 27 May 1878
response: The MCC team, captained by Arthur Ridley of Hampshire, was relatively strong and included eight players who represented England during their careers. These were W. G. Grace (Gloucestershire), A. N. Hornby (Lancashire), A. J. Webbe (Middlesex), Wilfred Flowers (Nottinghamshire), George Hearne (Kent), George Vernon (Middlesex), Alfred Shaw (Nottinghamshire) and Fred Morley (Nottinghamshire). The other two, both recognised first-class players, were Nottinghamshire wicketkeeper Frederick Wyld and the amateur batsman Clement Booth of Hampshire).
